section.title: numbered list
section.t:
A numbered list:
one two three

section.title: ordered list (letters)
section.t:
An ordered list using letters:
one two three one two three one two three one two three one two three one two three one two three one two three one two three one two three

section.title: no explicit counters
section.t:
Example for numbered list with user-defined-format:
R1 R2

Same with character-based numbering:
c-a c-b

section.title: with explicit counters
section.t:
A few requirements:
req R1 req R2

More requirements:
req R3 req R4

A few rules:
rule R1 rule R2 rule R3

section.title: spanx
section.t: Here is a carriage return inside a spanx element.

texttable.preamble: The list of valid keywords are:
texttable.c: try to enforce the ID-nits conventions and DTD validity
when producing a txt/nroff file, try to conserve vertical whitespace
if compact is "yes", then setting this to "no" will make things a little less compact
an integer hint indicating how many contiguous lines are needed at this point in the output
texttable.postamble: Remember, that as with everything else in XML, keywords and values are case-sensitive.

texttable.title: a table with no borders
texttable.preamble: The table below should appear with no borders.
The table below should appear with borders just around the headers.
So, putting it all together, we have, e.g.,
texttable.postamble: which is a very simple example.

  return -1;
}

<CODE ENDS>

  return -1;
}

  return -1;
}

<CODE ENDS>

section.title: xrefs
section.t: This section contains test cases for <xref/>, testing 9 different types of targets. Each target is tested for all possible values of the @format attribute, and for <xref/> elements with and without content. These tests were contributed by Erik Wilde.

section.title: Test Targets
section.t: This section contains a couple of markup constructs carrying anchors (this is paragraph 1).
Some regular paragraph text... (this is paragraph 2)

section.title: Extensions
section.t: These are tests for extensions done in rfc2629.xslt. Do not expect them to work out-of-the-box in xml2rfc.

postal.street: MIT Laboratory for Computer Science, NE43-356

author.organization: Department of Information and Computer Science

reference.annotation: This RFC will soon be updated, check for the latest draft.

abstract.t: This document defines the "xml2rfc" version 2 vocabulary: an XML-based language used for writing RFCs and Internet-Drafts.
Version 2 represents the state of the vocabulary (as implemented by several tools and as used by the RFC Editor) around 2014.

front.title: SHA-3 derived functions: cSHAKE, KMAC, TupleHash and ParallelHash
